title: Medicare calls operation on baby with no ears a 'cosmetic surgery'
text:
A baby who was born with no ears is unable to have an operation to allow him to hear as Medicare considers it cosmetic surgery and will not cover it.

Andre Tilbaroo was born with a condition called microtia bilateral, which effects one in 25,000 children and means he was born without ear canals.

The 16-month-old boy, who lives in Rockhampton, Queensland, wears a special hearing aid band around his head, and his mother Samantha Jane Bryant has tried to organise an operation for Andre to get 3D ears.

The expensive operation is not covered by Medicare, who consider the operation to be a cosmetic surgery.

Andre Tilbaroo (pictured) was born with a condition called microtia bilateral, which means he was born without ear canals

Miss Bryant told 7News she has struggled in her battle for her son.

'You can't describe wanting something for your kid so much, makes me a bit upset, it would mean the world,' Miss Bryant said.

'You don't want your kid going through life thinking he's abnormal or has something wrong with him.'

Andre requires regular treatment from several different doctors, needing to fly to Brisbane numerous times a year to see different specialists.

Miss Bryant has been forced to become a full-time carer for Andre, which is putting a financial strain on the family.

The Bryant family have set up a GoFundMe to raise money for Andre and his ongoing treatment.

Samantha Jane Bryant (pictured with her son Andre) said 'you don't want your kid going through life thinking he's abnormal or has something wrong with him'
